This place makes me feel at ease.
When I'm here, I'm free from the shackles of the world outside.
I don't have appearances to keep up. I don't have to pretend like I care about my work.
I remember my dinner with Rin.
Now that I think about it, neither she nor her mother appear anywhere in these diaries.
I've read months' worth of entries at this point.
And not a single page mentions Rin, even in passing.
I feel my eyes getting tired and look away from the pages.
I take my phone out of my pocket.
it's around 8 p.m.
The last two days, Rin invited me out around this hour.
I wonder if I've fractured our relationship with my criticism yesterday.
I stare at the static screen for a while, then stow it back into my pocket and continue reading the diaries.
But soon my eyes are glazing over and nothing sticks with me.
I keep pulling out my phone and opening up my chat with Rin.
She hasn't sent anything.
"I'll go home for today."
I send her a message as I lock the door on my way out.
She replies straight away.
"Good job."
That's all.
The silence at home is becoming more and more agonizing.
I stare down at the lunch box I got from the convenience store.
It feels so strange.
This is how I've had dinner for most of my marriage.
Alone in the living room, eating with a spoon in one hand and a book in the other.
The day my wife left this house was the first day I shared a meal with Rin.
It's only happened twice.
We've only eaten together those two times.
Yet losing that is making me feel so, well, lost.
It's making me feel more lonely than my wife's departure did.
I've been alone for the last 20 years, yet it's like I'm only starting to feel it now.
I keep wondering how Rin's day is going.
Do her thoughts keep turning to yesterday like mine do?
I start hating myself, as usual.
These worries I'm having are more like what someone Rin's age might have.
I look around the living room.
Digging in my heels and trying to argue would be a pain.
Besides, I can't deny that I'm in the wrong.
This place will probably not be my home for much longer.
I no longer have any appearances to keep up.
If I prefer spending time with Rin to eating alone, all I have to do is invite her out.
So what if I'm the teacher and she the student?
That's just one aspect of the positions we happen to be in right now. A label that doesn't have anything to do with us as individuals.
I'm sure Rin must be thinking the same way. She wanted to spend time with me, after all.
It's Friday.
Tomorrow, I can spend the whole day at Shuho's studio.
And then I'll invite Rin out to dinner.
As soon as I leave home, I drop her a message letting her know I'm heading to the studio.
But I receive no response from her.
When I reach the apartment complex, I slow down my pace.
I decide not to go in until she gives me permission.
I feel like it's important to keep at least that boundary.
I check my phone.
She hasn't even read the message yet.
I lean on a wall by the entrance and wait for a while.
"I'm here."
Twenty minutes have passed since I sent that last message.
She still hasn't read it.
Residents of the building come and go in front of me.
I'm going to draw attention to myself if I keep hanging around here.
It's not like I'm doing anything wrong, but I decide to go somewhere else while I await her response.
After a short walk, I find a diner.
There are a few families waiting to be seated by the entrance, but I get to go in first since there's a table for two free.
I get myself some coffee from the free refill machine and take a look around the place before sitting down.
It's all families enjoying the weekend as far as the eye can see.
I wonder what it means to be a dad.
The thought just pops into my head.
I feel like all the men sitting here with their families must have the answer to that question.
They all look younger than me.
About the same age as Watanabe, I'd say.
But they undoubtedly have that air of fatherhood about them.
I wonder at what point a father gets that fatherly look.
It's not like men go through the physical ordeal that women undergo to give birth.
If you spend every day with your child, does that naturally make you a father, in time?
I look at the families enjoying themselves and realize that I'll probably never have a weekend like this in my life, considering my future prospects.
I turn my attention to my phone and press the power button to light up the screen.
There are no new messages.
She hasn't even read them.
This is the first time I've gone so long without an answer from her.
What is Rin doing right now?
The smoke from the mini grill billows up into my face.
Is it ready?
I cut the sausage in half and spear each piece with a toothpick, just like they showed me.
I carefully serve them up on one of the small plastic plates I was told to use.
I raise my face from the plate and look ahead.
I'm behind a food counter in the supermarket.
Everyone's walking by slowly, looking at the food on offer.
I take a deep breath.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Welcome...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Would you like a sample?
My timid words disappear into the bustle of the store.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Welcome...
No one stops to look.
I feel so hopeless.
The sausages I cooked are going cold.

texts.name: Manager
texts.text: You need to be louder.
I look back and see the nice man who showed me the ropes of the job this morning.
I got so spooked I almost missed what he said entirely.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm sorry...

texts.name: Manager
texts.text: You'll get used to it. Everyone's shy at first.

texts.name: Manager
texts.text: You don't remember the clerks when you're the customer, do you? Don't worry, no one's judging you here. They just come to buy food.
After saying that, the man walks onto the sales floor shouting "welcome" really loudly.
He's shouting, but no one reacts to him.
I see. Right now I'm just part of the furniture.
My voice is like the background music of the supermarket.
I take another deep breath.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Welcome! This is a special sampling campaign! Feel free to help yourself!

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Welcome! They're fresh and hot! Come and get yours!

texts.name: Old lady
texts.text: Oh, can I try some?
I don't even see the old lady who's walked up in front of me until she's already there.
I find it curious that she asks if she can have some when she's already grabbed a sausage.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yes! Go ahead!

texts.name: Old lady
texts.text: Thank you, sweetie. Don't mind if I do.
She pops a sausage in her mouth, throws the plastic plate in the trash, and leaves.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Welcome! We're holding a sampling campaign! Feel free to try some!
When I raise my voice...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Ah, go ahead!
A balding old man approaches and takes a sample.
He's wearing a jacket with an unusual amount of pockets.
I wonder if he uses all of those.
While I wonder about his jacket, he takes a sausage and eats it.

texts.name: Bald old guy
texts.text: This is pretty good.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Thank you!
I made a sale!
The man who just sampled the sausages purchased some.
I'm actually doing my job now.
I watch him walk away, then keep going renewed resolve.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Welcome!
I open the next bag of sausages while I shout, cut them up, and begin cooking them up on the mini grill.
By the time the sun sets, I still haven't received a reply from Rin.
I finished reading the book I thankfully thought to bring with me.
It's a little past 6 p.m.
I put down my collection of Akutagawa's short stories and take a look around the diner again.
The customers are different, but what hasn't changed is the happy and cheerful bustle of families having a good time together. I feel completely removed from it all.
If I lose Shuho's studio...
Will the rest of the world become this unfamiliar and uncomfortable for me?
How on earth did I manage to live until today?
How did I keep myself sane?
Perhaps just having a family, even if was the faint illusion of one...
Perhaps that's what kept me stable all these years.
But all of that is gone now.
Without contact with Rin and access to that room, it's like I'm not connected to anything in the whole world.
I let out a small, inaudible sigh as I leave my seat.
Even when the sun goes down, it's still hot and humid outside.
Feeling a little silly for not having dinner while I was at the diner, I sigh. As I walk, I feel my phone vibrate in my pocket.
I stop, take it out, and stare at the screen.
It's a message from Rin.
"Are you free tonight?"
I simply stare at the message for a moment.
My heart starts beating a little faster.
It's kind of sad and funny that such a simple message can make me react like this.
I feel so pathetic for clinging to Rin like this.
But the excitement is so great I can't contain it.
"I do, let's have dinner together," I write.
And I press the send button.
The message is marked as read as soon as I send it.
It takes another moment for her to respond.
"I'll be waiting at the usual spot."
And below her message, there's an image of a little bird dressed up as a Daruma doll.
A Java sparrow?
Did Rin send this?
Does it mean she's in a good mood?
I stow the phone back in my pocket and rush to the usual spot.
I go at a light jog, and find her standing like always, holding a shopping bag with both hands.
She's holding a supermarket bag instead of her usual bag.
When she sees me, she looks surprised.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Huh? You weren't in the studio?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Ah, err, that was the plan.
She tilts her head to the side in confusion.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I wanted to wait until you gave me the okay to go in.
Her eyes open wide as the realization dawns upon her.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But I gave you the key! You could have just gone in anyway!

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I figure it's really your studio now, so I wouldn't want to trespass.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: So you stayed outside all day?
I nod.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I see. I'm so sorry. I thought you were in there already.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's fine. It wasn't a bad weekend.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You're too uptight sometimes.
She lets out one of those cute giggles.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Where did you go?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Some diner around here.
I glance down at the bag she's carrying.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: And you? Went shopping?
She gives me a small nod.
Then she flashes me a meaningful smile.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Professor, can I cook for you again today?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Huh?
She looks up at me, the smile on her face only growing bigger.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It won't be anything as fancy as yesterday, though.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'd love to try again, if that's okay.
I take another look at the bag she's holding.
It's a plastic bag with the logo of a major retailer, and it's full of what I assume is ingredients.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You want to cook again?
She gives one firm nod and lifts the bag a little.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I bought it all with my own money. I want to treat you properly.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Your money?
She nods enthusiastically.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That's fine, right?
I'm sitting at Rin's table again.
She's in the kitchen, sorting the ingredients as she takes them out of the bag.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: By your own money, you mean...
She turns my way and gives me a bright smile.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I've been working part-time.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Part-time?
I repeat her words back like a parrot.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: There aren't many jobs where you can just show up whenever you like and get paid immediately.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Why so sudden?
She raises her face and turns her eyes to me.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Didn't you tell me to?!

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Yeah, but I wasn't expecting you do it the next day!

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Is it that strange?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Nah, just surprising. A welcome surprise.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm glad.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I feel like it was worth it just to see the surprise on your face.
Rin teases me as she takes out carrots, onions, and potatoes.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: What kind of job?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Hawking food samples.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You? Really?
She frowns at me.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: What about it?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Nothing, it's just that...
Her, yelling at people to try food samples?
It's a little hard to imagine.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's just kind of hard to imagine you working in a supermarket.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You know, since it's such a bustling place and all. That's not really your scene, is it?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I decided to try working there exactly because of that! Didn't you say assuming things about people is bad?
She sounds displeased.
I'm so thoroughly schooled that I can't help but laugh.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Yeah, you're right, prejudice is bad. There's nothing wrong with that kind of work. What were you giving out samples of?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Sausages.
She takes a package of sausages from the bag and holds it up for me to see.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You bought those?
She nods.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Guess I fell for my own sales pitch.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Did you have fun?
She gives a vague nod.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It was really stressful at first, but I did enjoy it a bit by the end.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: They got mad at me for a lot of little things.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: And I was told I was too quiet so many times.
I can't help but chuckle.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But I think I understand what you were trying to say now.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: How so?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Shopping with money you earned yourself really is more fun.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I couldn't buy much, though.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Are you sure you wanna spend your first paycheck on making food for me?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Of course. I earned it because I wanted to give you a treat.
She beams at me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'm honored.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That wine was really expensive, wasn't it? I'm sorry for making you pay for it.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Earning money is so hard...

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Hahah...
As I laugh out loud, Rin blushes fiercely.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Hey, what's with you today?! Are you making fun of me?!

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: No way. I would never.
She glares at me like a cat about to pounce.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You're just too sweet.
That does nothing to loosen her sulky expression.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'm really happy that you took my words to heart and are trying to improve yourself.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It makes me feel like I still have some kind of bond connecting me with something.
Her expression changes to one of surprise as she stares at me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'll accept your kindness today.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Thank you, really.
After staring at me for a moment, a smile slowly crosses her face.
Looks like that did the trick.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yes.
I watch her at work in the kitchen for a while.
As I do, I feel my nervous heart slowly regain its normal beat.
She keeps on cooking in silence.
Watching her go to and fro makes a kind of affection that I've never felt before swell in my heart.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Want me to take a guess?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: About what you're cooking.
She looks at me, clearly surprised.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Curry.
Her eyes widen for a moment.
And then she laughs.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Well guessed!

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I figured.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You said you're always up for curry, right? Plus it's easy to make, and the ingredients are cheap.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Don't think I'll ever have enough of curry. It's good because you can eat it with one hand. I always read a book with the other.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Jinbocho style.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That's news to me.
Rin giggles as she stirs the big pot.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I can help if you want. I really don't mind.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Even elementary students can manage curry. Just sit back and relax.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Gotcha.
She giggles, and I get comfortable in my seat.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I hope you like it.
She presents me with a plate of curry with rice, and a huge bowl of salad.
She also sets down a plate with a bunch of fried sausages in the middle of the table.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It looks delicious.
For some reason, she laughs.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Is that supposed to be praise?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'm pretty sure it was.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Well, it's hard to mess up curry, isn't it?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You'd be surprised. I've had my share of bad curry over the years.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's quite possible to make bad curry, as unlikely as it sounds.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: So?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Yours looks really delicious.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Perhaps the best looking curry I've ever seen.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Ahahah!
She laughs out loud.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You just weren't thinking too hard about what you said, huh?
She quirks an amused little smile.
Helpless, I simply nod.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Thank you very much.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Uh...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Let's eat.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I hope it's at least more delicious than that bad curry you mentioned just now.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: We'll see about that.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yes.
I take a spoonful and bring it to my mouth.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Mmh...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: How is it?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's really damn good.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I just used normal cheap curry powder, though.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: No, it's really good. I'm not lying.
I really am not.... this time.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's way better than the stew from last time.
With her eyes still on me, she blushes a little.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm glad.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I've been eating out for years. It's been so long since I tasted real home cooking.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Years?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It warms my cockles, I mean it. It's really good.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm happy to hear that.
I take another bite and don't stop.
She slowly eats away at her plate too.
I glance at the sausages lined up in the middle of the table.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: And the sausages are a nice bonus.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yeah. I feel like I've cooked enough sausages for a lifetime.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I sure wasn't expecting them along with curry.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I haven't eaten a single one yet! I kinda wanted to try them after cooking so many.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Makes sense.
I stab one with my fork and take it to my mouth.
She does the same and slowly savors it.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: So, how is it?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Surprisingly...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: ...plain.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Pfft...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Heheh.
We both laugh together for a while.
After we're finished, I wash the dishes.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You made me dinner with your first ever paycheck. Let me do this much.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Oh, you really don't need to...
Rin watches distractedly as I wash the dishes.
As I finish, I notice a package of instant coffee on the kitchen table.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Oh, coffee. Mind if I make some?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yes, go ahead. I bought it for you, actually.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Really?
She nods.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Thank you.
I see the mug I used last time and Rin's mug on the draining board.
I line up the cups and set the drip bags in them.
After adding a little bit of cold water to cool it, I pour the hot water between them.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Why do you add cold water?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I read that if the water's too hot, it ruins the scent.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Whoa, really?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I don't really mind when I'm making it just for myself, though.
I tell her with a sad smile.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Well, anyway, I hope you enjoy my special instant coffee. I'm very particular about it.
She giggles at that.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'll keep that in mind.
We sit facing each other at the table again.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You... came to read my father's diary today, right?
I nod.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: That was the plan.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: ...Is it really that interesting?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I mean, you've been reading it every day.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's strange. We've never met, but he feels really familiar somehow.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: If I'd known we were so alike, I would have dropped my stupid stubbornness and talked to him when we were in college.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Stubbornness? You were like that?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Back then I wanted to get my debut novel published too. Shuho's the one who made that dream come true right in front of me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...I didn't want to be one more in the crowd just looking up at him.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I was probably thinking that I was the only one among us who was seriously thinking of getting my stuff published and making a debut.
Suddenly, that little self-deprecating demon speaks into my ear.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I suppose I was thinking that I should at least win some rookie award before talking to him. So we could be on equal footing and all that.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: So that's why you didn't know him very well in college. I thought it strange, since you attended the same seminar.
I nod.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: That was more than twenty years ago.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: And in the end... I never managed to stand on equal terms with him.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Actually, I don't think anyone can ever stand on his level anymore.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I was only able to face him after his death. I'm just sympathizing with the statue of the man that was.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: And I think it could have only happened on these terms.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Ironic, isn't it?
I raise my head as she murmurs.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: ...don't think my father ever stood so high up.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: His works did sell really well. That's why I'm living in such an expensive place.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: And today I understood how grateful I should be for that.
Rin squints through the smoke rising from her mug.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But all I ever learned from him...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Was that he regretted me ever being born. Nothing besides that.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I don't think someone like that should be on the lofty pedestal you're placing him on.
I stay silent for a while.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Being a successful and acclaimed writer...

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...has little to do with how virtuous one is as a person.
She turns her eyes up to me and nods.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I know where you're coming from, but Hatano Shuho was...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Professor.
After gently cutting me off, she shakes her head.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You can't understand how I feel.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm sorry. I was the one who took you there.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: But I never imagined you would develop this admiration for him.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You want me to say he was an overrated writer? That in the end, he was just a bad person?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'm not blaming you for rightfully feeling the way you do. Don't get me wrong.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I just don't think repeating the same criticisms and blanket writing him out as a completely horrible person will help you move on either.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I don't think that will help you at all.
She's still staring down at the mug in front of her.
I heave a tired sigh.
Today, she went to work with the express intent of earning money to treat me to dinner with.
Why does it always end on a sour note because of my big mouth?

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to spoil the nice evening. I just really think you need to overcome that.
She raises her face and looks at me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Even if he was a failure as a parent, and even if he was a guy who got a woman he didn't love pregnant.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Even if his works don't speak to you on any level.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: The fact that his writing has saved many people is still true.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: And I believe the things he achieved as a writer are things only a great person in that field could do.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You need to separate the image of Shuho that he left you with from the image of the author that people who didn't know him have.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: If you can't reconcile that, you'll keep on feeling angry and sad.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I know that! I'm well aware of it!

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I know, but...
Rin trails off at the end, but I know what she meant to say.
"You don't understand."
"I know what I've lived. It's my truth."

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You can do it.
She looks up at me again.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You still have time. It'll be fine.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You took my preachy talk from yesterday on board and showed me just how much you grew in a matter of days.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You're sweet, honest, and young.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'm sure you'll grow into a wonderful woman.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: So it's fine. I know you can overcome this.
Still looking at me, she giggles.
Unsure what to make of it, I only stare.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: You know so much, but you don't understand a woman's heart.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Uhh...

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I think I'm very stubborn myself.
Suddenly, she exudes a lot more confidence. She doesn't look like a girl being reprimanded anymore, but a woman.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That's why I invited you today.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Do you know what I'm trying to say?
I think upon her words for a long moment.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I don't want you to treat me like a little girl.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: And I don't want to play second fiddle to anyone else in your heart.
She has a confident, bewitching smile on her face.
My eyes are drawn to it like moths to a flame.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I can't bear you seeing everything I do under the shadow of my father.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: That's why I made you dinner today with my own hard earned money. It has nothing to do with that man.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I just couldn't accept you seeing me as a helpless, dependent girl. That's pretty stubborn, isn't it?
It's not a rhetorical question.
Her sharp, almost icy stare seems to pierce through me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: ...I see.
She tilts her head to the side, waiting for me to keep going.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Okay. I'll remember that. I won't treat you like a kid anymore.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: You're not my student when we're here. I'll try to put that out of my mind.
Pleased, Rin's smile slowly widens.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Thank you for the dinner. It was delicious.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I'm glad you enjoyed it.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: So, next week.
She raises her eyebrows and looks at me curiously.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Can I spend the night there?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: There? You mean at the studio?
I nod.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: It's almost summer break, so...
I stop myself.
What am I gonna do during the break?
Edit the manuscript I wrote?
Write something new altogether?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: I don't really mind.
Her eyes wander for a moment, but then they settle on me.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Just please, don't use the bathroom.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Don't even go in there.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: It's like stepping into death itself. At least that's how I felt.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: If you can promise me that, then you can stay.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Okay.
I give her a firm nod.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I promise.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: All right.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Thanks.
After putting on my shoes, I turn to her.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Well, I guess this is it.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Can I...

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Hm?

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Can I cook dinner for you again?
I look down at her, at a loss for words.
She looks down, obviously bashful. I respond with a firm nod.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: I'd love that.
She looks up again, beaming at me.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: But next time let's go shopping together. I'll pay.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Yes. Then let's go tomorrow. Together.
I nod again.

texts.name: Rin
texts.text: Have a good night.

texts.name: Arishima
texts.text: Yeah, you too.
I remember the first time we spoke...
Back then, I thought that I shouldn't get closer than necessary to one of my students.
But now she's been making dinner for me in her own apartment.
Perhaps I changed without even realizing it myself.
Yes. I must have changed.
Just like the fathers I saw today at the diner turned into family men at some point.
I'm changing so gradually that I'm not even aware of it.
I started writing a novel again, divorced my wife, and I'm reading the diaries of a dead man.
It's such a huge change.
And it all began with my encounter with Rin.
That rainy day we shared an umbrella under the cold downpour.
It was the day of the funeral for the old seminar professor.
Death was present on the day we met, too.
We met in the wake of a death, and came together again over the death of another person; Hatano Shuho.
If this was a novel...
Naturally, the final destination of the character would be death.
That way, the story would feature death in all three acts.
I laugh to myself.
I see now.
If I were headed towards death...
Then my life would almost be...
...like a story.
